intro: Galium simense, commonly known as sleepygrass, is a flowering plant native to the wetlands and marshes of eastern North America. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its prostrate growth habit and small, opposite leaves. The plant produces clusters of white or pale pink flowers in late spring to early summer. Its flowering stems are often covered in fine hairs, and the leaves are typically oval to lance-shaped. Galium simense is often found in moist, acidic soils and is an important component of wetland ecosystems.
